Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Phylogeny, reticulate evolution, and historical biogeography in the Hawaiian lobeliad genera Cyanea and Clermontia
Award.AbstractNarration:
Adaptive radiations, where a group of organisms has radiated to perform a number of ecological roles, offer an opportunity to investigate the mechanisms that allow species to diversify rapidly within a limited geographical area. Members of the lobelia plant family (Lobeliaceae) restricted to the Hawaiian Islands have undergone a remarkable divergence in habitat, growth form, leaf size and shape, floral morphology, and mechanism of seed dispersal, and are considered one of the best examples of an adaptive radiation in plants. Previous studies have shown that this group of 140 species was derived from a single colonization 13 million years ago, long before many of the Hawaiian islands of today had emerged from the Pacific. Hawaiian lobeliads now represent 12% of the native Hawaiian flora and are the most species-rich plant lineage found on any single group of oceanic islands on Earth. The two largest genera, Cyanea and Clermontia, comprising approximately 100 species form the largest sublineage within the group. Previous phylogenetic analyses of Cyanea-Clermontia were inconclusive due to a combination of limited sampling within the group and insufficient DNA sequence variation to reconstruct a well-supported estimate of relationships. Cyanea-Clermontia, by its very size, ecological and morphological diversity, and high proportion of species restricted to single islands (each of known age), offers unique opportunities for studying adaptive radiation, speciation, and historical biogeography. Understanding relationships within this lineage could provide new insights into the rise of plant and animal diversity on Hawaii, and identify traits associated with a tendency to become rare or extinct. This project will (1) broadly train a graduate student in plant systematics and historical biogeography analyses; (2) develop molecular phylogenetic analysis pipelines to aid in the study of other recent radiations; (3) produce a well-documented collection of DNA samples to permit future studies of this important group; and (4) create a website on the diversification of native Hawaiian lobeliads, to disseminate findings to a broad range of amateur botanists and lobeliad enthusiasts.

Next-generation DNA sequencing data will be used to infer phylogenies of Cyanea-Clermontia from whole-chloroplast genomes and >400 nuclear genes for all living species sampled across their range. Analyses of these data will permit derivation of species trees and networks, analysis of hybridization, introgression, and other forms of reticulate evolution (important in Clermontia), reconstruct its geographic spread through time, and infer the pattern and tempo of evolution of key morphological and ecological character-states using a variety of tree- and network-based approaches.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Introduction and methods

The Hawaiian lobeliads are among the most remarkable cases of adaptive radiation and species diversification in any group of flowering plants worldwide. Based on earlier research, they appear to be the largest group (6 genera, 141 species) restricted to any single oceanic island or archipelago, and lobeliad species have diverged from each other ecologically in growth form (trees, treelets, vines, succulents), flower size and shape (adapted to native birds and moths), mode of seed dispersal (fleshy fruits vs. wind-dispersed seeds), habitat (sea level to 2000 m), and photosynthetic rates adapted to the different amounts of light present in their native habitats (tropical rain forests, cloud forests, bogs, rocky outcrops, sea cliffs) Previous estimates suggest that the ancestor of the Hawaiian lobeliads arrived in the Hawaiian chain 10 to 16 million years ago, long before any of the tall islands currently above sea level emerged from the Pacific. Finally, most species are restricted to single islands, and island age increases in regular fashion from 0.4 to 5.1 million years in moving northwest from the youngest island (Hawai’i) to the oldest (Kauaʻi and Niʻihau); a series of pinnacles, shoals, atolls, and submersed seamounts of increasingly older age (up to 80 Mya) continues to the northwest, then the north to the Aleutian Trench.

The Hawaiian lobeliads are thus a model system for evolutionary research, and we have already learned much regarding their phylogeny (evolutionary relationships), history of spread down the Hawaiian chain, ecological and physiological divergence, and rates of species diversification. However, previous studies were constrained by including only a fraction of extant species, by limits to resolving relationships based on the few DNA sequences included and relatively young age of the group, and failure to investigate possible hybridization.  These limitations apply to almost all lineages of Hawaiian plants studied to date. We therefore used a far more powerful approach to reconstruct the family tree of the Hawaiian lobeliads, using sequences of entire chloroplast genomes (plastomes) and 389 nuclear loci to infer relationships of 96 of 107 extant species, screen for hybridization, and conduct time-dependent analyses of historical biogeography. Research used DNA samples from previous research by Givnish and colleagues, and new samples gathered by DDIG recipient Steve Hunter and his colleagues on all the tall islands. Vouchers for new samples were deposited at BISH and WIS. Plastome data include 147 samples x 139,453 base pairs, excluding one copy of the inverted repeat; nuclear data matrix includes 389 genes of length 340-4484 base pairs. Data analysis required > 1.8 million computer hours on the HTCondor system at UW-Madison.

Key findings

This study resulted in a time-calibrated phylogeny for almost all extant species of the Hawaiian lobeliads. Four important results are:

1. There was a rapid radiation between 15-16 million years (Mya) that produced five clades (lineages consisting of all descendants from a single ancestor: Cyanea + Clermontia (Hawaiian rain and cloud forests), Apetahia (Society Islands cloud forests), Lobelia § Revolutella (Hawaiian rocky outcrops), Brighamia + Delissea (Hawaiian sea cliffs and mesic scrub), and Lobelia § Galeatella + Trematolobelia (Hawaiian bogs and boggy forests). Lobelia § Galeatella and Trematolobelia diverged from each 13-14 Mya; Cyanea and Clermontia, 11-12 Mya; and Brighamia and Delissea, ca. 7 Mya. All these radiations predate the oldest tall islands currently above water (Kauaʻi and Niʻihau), implying that all eight major clades of Hawaiian lobeliads arrived on Kauaʻi via one or more inter-island dispersal events from now submersed islands. This initial rapid radiation involved specialization on different habitats by different lineages, as indicated above.

2. We found no evidence of hybridization between the eight major clades of Hawaiian lobeliads. However, hybridization does appear to have occurred with four of those clades: orange-fruited Cyanea, purple-fruited Cyanea, Clermontia, and Lobelia § Revolutella.

3. The most detailed study of historical biogeography conducted to date for any element of the Hawaiian flora supports the so-called progression rule, with almost all (34 of 35) inter-island dispersal events leading to speciation having been from one island to the next younger island in the chain; a single dispersal event involved dispersal that skipped across an intermediate island to an even younger island. This pattern strongly supports ecological and biogeography theory, which favors successful dispersal to the nearest, ecological unoccupied islands from a source island, which favors dispersal down the Hawaiian chain as new volcanic islands are formed as the Pacific Plate moves to the northwest past the Hawaiian hotspot at roughly 8.6 cm/year.

4. Despite the origins of all major clades from 7-16 Mya, several rapid bursts of recent speciation have occurred in several lineages (Cyanea § Rollandia on Oʻahu, Cyanea coriacea and relatives on Kauaʻi, Cyanea hirtella and allies on Kauaʻi, and Clermontia on the Big Island of Hawaiʻi) over the past 0.5-1.5 My, on both old and new islands.
